primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The Dayspring (God/Messiah) enters the darkness of the fallen human condition to restore creation and undo the disobedience of Adam through sacrificial death.

subject.identificatie: The Dayspring / The Lamb of God / Jesus Christ
tekstueel_bewijs: the dayspring from on high hath visited us
Jesus Christ... will undo the disobedience of Adam and Eve
the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world

object.identificatie: Restoration of creation / Light for those in darkness / Remission of sin
tekstueel_bewijs: To give light to them that sit in darkness
God creates a new heaven and a new earth

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Primordial Source
tekstueel_bewijs: The One who in the beginning said, 'Let there be light'
That is the promise of God in Jesus Christ

ontvanger.identificatie: The fallen humanity (those in the shadow of death)
tekstueel_bewijs: To give light to them that sit in darkness... and that means all of us
I will rejoice in Jerusalem, and be glad in my people
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer identifies as the Receiver (the one sitting in darkness).

helper.identificatie: John the Baptist / The Preacher / Advent (as a season)
tekstueel_bewijs: thou shalt go before the face of the Lord to prepare his ways
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject; the human figures are merely 'voices' (helpers).
helper.rol_van_geest: Implicit indwelling power that 'creates charity' and 'works wonders' in the believer.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin / The Shadow of Death / The Serpent / Human Disobedience
tekstueel_bewijs: the darkness and the shadow of death
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad behavior but an ontological condition ('fallen human condition') and a cosmic history ('disobedience of Adam') that requires a 'great reversal'.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer's response: waiting, repenting, and decreasing so Christ may increase.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer / The Preacher
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (human response) is framed as a necessary posture to receive the primary program (God's arrival).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God is going to restore his original creation
The Savior will create charity in you

voorbeelden: He has had everything pretty much the way he wanted it
understanding why and how we sit in darkness
The Savior will create charity in you
The Lord will work a wonder of forgiveness in you

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes that the 'ability' (Pouvoir) to be patient or charitable is a gift created by God, not a human effort.

primaire_tegenstelling.niet_s2: Anticipation (Not yet fully Light, but no longer just Death)

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Darkness) through ~S2 (Waiting/Advent) to S1 (New Creation).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the 'Great Reversal' where the Lamb takes S2 to grant S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; sin is described as 'smoke in God's nostrils' and 'tragic fallen condition'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. While it calls for repentance, the 'engine' of change is God's action. God is the subject of the transformative verbs.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Many of us... have taken John the Baptist as our patron saint.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as the source of human virtue
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: If you are not charitable, the Savior will create charity in you.
Christ makes himself the substitute for the lambs... satisfaction for sin.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: John the Baptist is used as a model, but specifically a model of 'disappearing' so that Christ can be the Subject.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides this: John is not the hero, but the 'voice' pointing to the Hero.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and hope; the burden of 'creating' virtue is shifted to God.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'darkness' of the Alzheimer's story to the 'Dayspring' of the Benedictus is perfectly integrated.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'already' (Dayspring has come) and 'not yet' (waiting in darkness).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Christ makes himself the substitute for the lambs... satisfaction for sin.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit (via the Savior) endows the subject with 'Pouvoir' (ability) to forgive and be patient.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; sin is an 'uncompromising condemnation' and a 'tragic condition' that humans cannot fix.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the primary Subject. The human 'Subject' is correctly positioned as a 'Voice' or 'Receiver'.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly heavy on Devoir (Must) in the middle, but corrected by Pouvoir (Can) at the end.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the concluding emphasis on God's enabling power.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Ensure the 'must decrease' is seen as a result of Christ's 'increase' rather than a work of will.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (The Lamb) clearly precedes and enables Ethics (Charity/Forgiveness).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in maintaining the 'Grammar of Grace'. The preacher avoids the trap of turning Advent into a 'to-do list' of waiting, instead presenting it as a space where God acts upon the helpless.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While rhetoric would focus on the moving Alzheimer's anecdote, semiotics reveals that the anecdote serves to establish the 'Opponent' (Darkness) which only the 'Subject' (Dayspring) can defeat.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Luke 1; semiotics shows how the preacher assigns the 'role' of Zechariah's prophecy to the modern hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas's model exposes that the 'Helper' (John/Preacher) is functionally distinct from the 'Subject' (Christ), preventing the preacher from accidentally becoming the hero of the sermon.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'Advent' itself as a semiotic space of transition between the 'Not Yet' and the 'Already'.
